title: Will Rogers Turnpike
text:
The Will Rogers Turnpike is a <a href="freeway">freeway</a>-standard <a href="toll%20road">toll road</a> in the northeast portion of the <a href="U.S.%20state">U.S. state</a> of <a href="Oklahoma">Oklahoma</a>. The highway begins as a continuation of the <a href="Creek%20Turnpike">Creek Turnpike</a> in <a href="Tulsa%2C%20Oklahoma">Tulsa</a>, continuing northward from the <a href="I-44%20%28OK%29">I-44</a>/<a href="US-412%20%28OK%29">US-412</a> interchange there to the <a href="Missouri">Missouri</a> state line west of <a href="Joplin%2C%20Missouri">Joplin, Missouri</a>. The turnpike carries the I-44 designation for its entire length. The turnpike is long and costs $4.75 (for a two-axle vehicle) to drive one way. The Will Rogers Turnpike opened to traffic on June 28, 1957. It was designated as I-44 in 1958. It is named for <a href="Will%20Rogers">Will Rogers</a>, "Oklahoma's Favorite Son".
Route description.
The Will Rogers Turnpike begins at an interchange between <a href="I-44%20%28OK%29">I-44</a>, <a href="US-412%20%28OK%29">US-412</a>, and the <a href="Creek%20Turnpike">Creek Turnpike</a> on the northeast side of Tulsa, straddling the line between <a href="Wagoner%20County%2C%20Oklahoma">Wagoner County</a> and <a href="Rogers%20County%2C%20Oklahoma">Rogers County</a>. The Creek Turnpike ends at this interchange, with northbound Creek Turnpike traffic continuing onto the Will Rogers Turnpike. I-44 eastbound traffic also merges into the turnpike here. The turnpike heads north to its first interchange, which provides an exit to East Pine Street for westbound traffic and an entrance to the eastbound turnpike. North of the Pine Street interchange, the highway curves to a more northeast course, crossing the <a href="Verdigris%20River">Verdigris River</a>. In <a href="Verdigris%2C%20Oklahoma">Verdigris</a>, the turnpike has an interchange at the eastern terminus of <a href="SH-266%20%28OK%29">SH-266</a>. The turnpike continues northeast to <a href="Claremore%2C%20Oklahoma">Claremore</a>, county seat of Rogers County, where it junctions <a href="SH-20%20%28OK%29">SH-20</a>; it also passes over <a href="SH-88%20%28OK%29">SH-88</a> in Claremore, with no access provided between the two highways. The turnpike then continues northeast out of Rogers County.
After leaving Rogers County, the Will Rogers Turnpike enters <a href="Mayes%20County%2C%20Oklahoma">Mayes County</a>. The only interchange in Mayes County is a partial interchange with <a href="SH-28%20%28OK%29">SH-28</a> west of <a href="Adair%2C%20Oklahoma">Adair</a>. Eastbound motorists can exit the turnpike at SH-28 and motorists on SH-28 can join the turnpike heading westbound. From this interchange, SH-28 continues northeast, entering <a href="Craig%20County%2C%20Oklahoma">Craig County</a>.
North of <a href="Big%20Cabin%2C%20Oklahoma">Big Cabin</a>, the Will Rogers Turnpike comes to a junction with <a href="US-69%20%28OK%29">US-69</a>. Just northeast of this interchange is the only mainline barrier <a href="toll%20plaza">toll plaza</a> on the turnpike. After the toll plaza, the highway passes under the <a href="McDonald%27s">McDonald's</a> restaurant at the <a href="Vinita%2C%20Oklahoma">Vinita</a> service plaza (see below). On the east side of Vinita, the road comes to an interchange with <a href="US-60%20%28OK%29">US-60</a> and US-69. From Vinita, the turnpike continues northeast out of Craig County.
The final county that the Will Rogers Turnpike serves is <a href="Ottawa%20County%2C%20Oklahoma">Ottawa County</a>. The first interchange in Ottawa County lies northeast of <a href="Afton%2C%20Oklahoma">Afton</a>; here, motorists can access <a href="US-59%20%28OK%29">US-59</a>, US-60, and US-69. The turnpike continues to its final interchange, near the county seat, <a href="Miami%2C%20Oklahoma">Miami</a>. This interchange serves <a href="SH-10%20%28OK%29">SH-10</a>. Just north of this interchange is a welcome center for westbound traffic. The highway continues northeast to the state line. I-44 continues east into <a href="Newton%20County%2C%20Missouri">Newton County, Missouri</a> toward Joplin and <a href="Springfield%2C%20Missouri">Springfield</a>.
History.
Because the Will Rogers Turnpike was built prior to authorization of the <a href="Interstate%20Highway%20System">Interstate Highway System</a> (in 1956), it uses a different set of design standards than today's. As the road has been rebuilt, this is being brought in line with current design practice.
The original route of the Turnpike continued straight into and through Tulsa, becoming Skelly Drive in town (where tolls are not charged). The westernmost portion of the Will Rogers Turnpike was modified so that the Creek and Will Rogers Turnpikes form one road, with motorists required to exit at an interchange to stay on I-44. The original interchange was changed due to numerous difficulties for semis trying to merge into the single lane going to I-44 and Route 66. The new interchange was incorporated into an upgrade of US 412, with provisions for future expansion of the turnpike over a decade later, creating the Creek Turnpike bypass around the Metropolitan area, connecting back to the Turner Turnpike. The remaining pavement of the old alignment is now used as a training ground for the <a href="Oklahoma%20Highway%20Patrol">Oklahoma Highway Patrol</a>, among others.
Tolls.
A two-axle vehicle currently pays $5.00 ($4.40 with Pikepass) to drive the full length of the Turnpike. The Will Rogers Turnpike (as well as the <a href="Turner%20Turnpike">Turner Turnpike</a> on the other side of Tulsa) uses a somewhat unusual tolling system. The Turnpike has only one barrier toll plaza, located southwest of Vinita, at which drivers pay the full toll and are issued a receipt. If one exits before reaching this plaza, the toll for the portion traveled is collected at the exit. If one's desired exit is located after the plaza, the motorist presents their receipt to the attendant, and the fare for the untraveled portion of the turnpike is refunded to the driver. Travelers exiting the turnpike westbound at Port of Catoosa or Pine Street, as well as at the two termini do not receive any refund. A similar situation exists for motorists entering the turnpike at an interchange. If one is entering in the direction away from the main toll plaza, the toll for the portion between the interchange and the terminus is collected at the ramp plaza; a refund receipt is still issued should the motorist exit at another interchange. Motorists entering in the direction toward the toll plaza are issued a ticket at the interchange which shows proof of entry. This ticket is then presented to the toll collector at the main toll plaza (or the desired exit, if before the main plaza), and the fare for the untraveled portion of the turnpike is deducted from their toll. This system was implemented in 1992.
Services.
Law enforcement along the Will Rogers Turnpike is provided by <a href="Oklahoma%20Highway%20Patrol">Oklahoma Highway Patrol</a> Troop XA, a special troop assigned to the turnpike.
Vinita service plaza.
The Will Rogers Turnpike's most prominent service plaza lies between the toll plaza and the Vinita exit. The main feature of this toll plaza is a McDonald's <a href="bridge%20restaurant">bridge restaurant</a> spanning the turnpike. Customers can view the traffic passing beneath the restaurant from the dining area through windows overlooking the highway. At the front of the west anchor stands a statue of Will Rogers. A separate <a href="Phillips%2066">Phillips 66</a> <a href="gas%20station">gas station</a> is also available for both directions of travel at the plaza.
The architecture of the McDonald's building is dominated by golden arches on both sides of the building that appear from a distance to be not only the corporate symbol of the chain, but the primary supports for a <a href="through%20arch%20bridge">steel arch bridge</a> structure over the turnpike. Visitors to the eatery exit from either side of the interstate, and then enter through one of the sides and then proceed to the restaurant level via stairs or an elevator.
The building hosting the McDonald's restaurant was originally built when the turnpike opened in 1957 as one of the Glass House restaurants, owned by the now-defunct <a href="Interstate%20Hosts">Interstate Hosts</a> company. Because of this heritage, it is also known as the "Glass House McDonald's" and the "McDonald's Glass House Restaurant". the building originally operated as a <a href="Howard%20Johnson%27s">Howard Johnson's</a> restaurant.
The McDonald's is purported to be the "world's largest." However, the biggest temporary McDonald's in the world was opened during the <a href="2012%20Summer%20Olympics">2012 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="London">London</a>, which had but it was demolished after the 2012 Summer Olympics.
The building and service plaza closed on June 4, 2013, for a complete renovation. It reopened on December 22, 2014 with a McDonald's, <a href="Subway%20%28restaurant%29">Subway</a>, and <a href="Kum%20%26amp%3B%20Go">Kum & Go</a> gas stations. It reopened as the Will Rogers Archway.
Exit list.
Exit numbers follow <a href="Interstate%2044%20in%20Oklahoma">I-44</a> unless otherwise noted.
